												Although it's free, this game is short...and boring.You awake not knowing where you are. Alright, now what? There are no immediate clues as to what you should do at any point in the game. If you aren't used to thinking outside the box, then this game will give you a problem. The constant, "Hey, are you there?" after standing still for 10 seconds waiting for a hint was annoying. The voices weren't that great, either - they all sound computer generated. Although, according to the credits, different people played each character. The main character doesn't give many clues to what you have to do, either - he just says, "Why?" or, "Umm...no." or, "I don't think I need that." If you don't know that you have to throw the newspaper in the garbage can, grab some leather and matches, and start a fire, then you're stuck standing there until you can use your next hint. Fortunately, you only have to wait 2.5 minutes in between each one. But, as I said before, the constant, "Hey, are you there?" is annoying.Also, the storyline - it is intriguing as to what happened to the city and why/how he lost his memory, but the game doesn't give you any clues to that, even after completing it. Yes, it is the first chapter, and yes, I know more will probably be revealed in future chapters, and that is why much isn't revealed, but after finishing the game and still not knowing close to anything, I really have no desire to play the future chapters, especially if they are as bland as this one. I know you can't expect too much from the point & click genre, but this looks like it was made more than two years ago. The artwork is pretty bland, even for a two dimensional game, and I got tired of looking at it after a while.If you keep the audio in the default settings, you're likely to notice that there are times when the music is way too loud when characters are talking. However this can be adjusted in the settings menu.If you're looking for a short game to pass some time, then this will keep you entertained for a bit. But if you're looking for an intriguing game that will always keep you on your toes, with good artwork and sound, then this isn't for you.One final thing....why is hypnotizing a rat an achievement? It does absolutely nothing to help you progress in any way. Just why.I'm sure someone will completely disagree with me and everything I said, but this is a review, and so it is my opinion. If the next installments are the same as this, I definitely won't be playing them, although I'll probably give the next one a try just to see. TL;DR - bad art, bad voices, too short, no clues for what to do next, bland storylineEDIT: I noticed the second chapter is available, however it isn't free. I would never pay for it especially considering how uninteresting the first chapter was. So going off of that I won't be trying it.

												The best word to summarise this game is "amateurish". While it's ok at its core, I can't recommend it while respecting your time, because it doesn't add anything to the genre while failing on some basic levels: The English voice acting is bad. And I mean really bad. It's literally the worst I've ever heard in my life. It's so bad that it's funny. They actually made the game worse by adding this content. This shouldn't be considered a show stopper, as you can just disable it, and I've recommended adventure games without voice acting before. But it's the first thing you'll notice and it does taint the experience unless you turn it off. Unfortunately, you'll be falling back on dialogue which is not much more believable than the voice acting. People just don't talk that way. There is also some English translation weirdness, but it's relatively minor. The UI breaks de facto adventure gaming standards. You have to double click to open a verb dial. You can also double click to navigate to the next screen, so single click is literally not needed in the game, making me wonder why they didn't just use single click everywhere, like virtually all other adventure games. This takes some getting used to. Breaking convention for no good reason is one thing, but breaking it while making things more awkard suggests no thought was given to this at all. Another example: rather than spacebar to highlight hotspots, the shortcut is ctrl-tab. CTRL-TAB! Fortunately there's also a button on the toolbar to do this, so no biggie. For the most part, the puzzle design is pretty good, but this is undermined by some classic design shortcomings: (a) One puzzle requires asking the same person the same question 3x until his answer changes. (b) Often, you won't be able to interact with an object until you examine it first, so I found myself trying [use] then [examine], and walking away fruitless, when [examine] then [use] would have produced a result. (c) The game suffers from the character having to learn things the player may already have thought of before an action can be taken, and it feels a bit patronising being forced to jump through hoops to do what you intended all along. The industry has long since moved on from these very oldschool design choices, as they increase the likeliness of needing a walkthrough to complete the game while adding no enjoyment, and it's disappointing to see them return in a modern game. On one playthrough (there is an achievement for completing the game twice; the only reason anyone would), an item I needed to complete the game never appeared in the inventory. This game is only 1 hour long, and that's a pretty horrid bug. Another time I was massive and walking on the ceiling, but exiting the screen fixed that.I guess to be fair I should speak to Reversion chapter 1's good points: The puzzles are generally interesting (though frequently undermined as summarised above). The game doesn't take itself too seriously, and has some humour including breaking the fourth wall. The art is decent enough, and suits the games often comical tone (but your walk animation is kinda amateur/hilarious). It's free (but it's really only a demo for the proceeding commercial chapters, and chapter 2 has a worse community rating than this). I honestly can't think of anything else. Does music which is just passable enough to not get on my nerves as it loops every 55 seconds count as a positve? What the hell, it does now.

												Oh those amnesia stories…how much I loath them. To me, those storylines are a total copout of trying to tell a suspenseful plot by ‘discovering’ your past. Yet some have done a reasonable job like Stalker and XIII. This game Reversion – The Escape is a difficult one to state whether this amnesia copout plotline holds up as it forms part of a trilogy. Being the first one, there’s not much to say as your main goal is to escape the hospital and because it only last one hour, its best-selling point is that it’s free, and there’s nothing wrong with that unless you want to continue on with the saga then you have to pay for them (I think it’s around $AUD 6 each).The game plays out as your typical point and click adventure game. Double left click to get the menu where you can talk / grab or examine or right click to access your inventory. You can also join items by dragging / dropping two items to make a third and some items are simply red herrings. So there’s nothing new presented here as far as adventure games are concerned.The puzzles presented are not challenging at all as the clues are quite obvious. Examples like ‘…for the moment’ triggers that you are missing some sort of action and so forth. Also there’s not a lot happening as it plays on one event leads on to another so you won’t be juggling many puzzles in one go. Thankfully the puzzles are all logical so it shouldn’t be too difficult to resolve them. Just examine and talk to everyone and you cannot fail.The game advertises that it plays homage to the old school adventure games. You can see this via the visuals as it all renders in 2D and actually does look nice. The character’s walking animation are quite stiff however you won’t be suffering from pixel hunting here. The musical scores are very pleasant to hear with sombre scores when doing some investigations and the title screen has an upbeat tempo. Sometimes I wonder if the game is an afterthought from the music itself. The voice acting is pretty decent too yet it has its odd moments of that ‘emotionless’ speech however nothing to cringe about.Because this game is free, you cannot argue how good / bad it is however because it forms part of a trilogy, I guess you can say you are getting an entrée before the main course. Yet the strongest feature for any adventure game is its storytelling however there’s nothing really thrilling about this one. If developers 3f interactive can pull it off with the next two and increase the length, then it would be a decent purchase overall. However time will tell if this is the case and as for me, the game wasn’t thrilling at all yet enjoyable enough to finish it off with all sixteen achievements earned.5 / 10

												I'm afraid I can't be totally objective, but here I go.This is the demo of a game, which is great because it is free, like most demos. After playing this one -as a demo- I would totally buy the rest of the game... BUT only if Chapter 2 isn't as short as this one.What I liked about this gamedemo (besides the beautiful Buenos Aires):The Argentinian mood: we don't really get to see the city of Buenos Aires (other than a glimpse of the Obelisc at the end), but the tango-inspired music and the Argentinian accent in the Spanish version are perfect. I haven't played the other languages, but even the casual cockyness of the characters is very Buenos Aires.The illustrations are nice and simple.The voice acting was quite good (again, I can only vouch for the Spanish version), with the participation of a well known Argentinian actor. Only a line here and there sounded a bit forced, but in general it was great, sounded natural and authentic. EXCEPT for the laughter. The two characters who laughed were awful at it, at least in Spanish.The little bits of humor, including Argentina as World Champion for the 6th time, which made me laugh in pain.There isn't pixel-hunting for that one item that kind of mimics with its background and gets you stuck in the game for ages. There aren't ridiculous combinations of items. Things are pretty logical.What I didn't like about this gamedemo:The gameplay becomes somewhat annoying. To interact with anything/anyone, you have to double-click on it, rather than the usual single click, and then decide if you want to look, use/take or speak.The only reason the gameplay doesn't get to be too annoying is that it's over before you get annoyed. However, if I consider it a demo, that's fine.All the puzzles are "inventory based" or just a series of actions, like asking more questions or using X on Y. These are all quite easy to figure out in this game. That's not so bad, but in the end it's not very challenging.All in all, I recommend anyone who likes classic point-and-click games to try this demo. I enjoyed it and now I'm curious about the rest.

Imho there are two good types of adventures: The funny ones and the ones with tension/ a deep story. This on lacks the entertaining fun, the monumental narrative and an satisfying ending. 												First, lets start with the Negatives:Voices: Everyone except the main chracter (who is a little annoying, but I personally like it) is bad. The girl has little to none emotion, the military dudes sound aweful, in particular the muscular guard. He sounds like an cheerful intern, not some buff, thugish soldier. The doctor was passable, but thats it.The gameplay: Some of the parts are comepletly impossiable without hints. For example, why would I think to use the fire extisher to knock out a guard? Why would I ask the bad-tempered dude what his problem was 3 times?!Speed: Other than double clicking to instantly move, the main chracter seems to like walk very slowly  , which can be annoying late in the game.Size: This game took me a half hour to finish. I Know this is your first chaper, and its free to boot, but couldn;t have added a little more content?And now for the good.Story: Intriguing. Why did this happen? Why has the city fallen apart? If this were a normal civil war, wouldn;t the city be in better shape? The amnesiac is typical fare, but the fate of the city is certinly a good start.Music: While loud at times, it was prett atmospheric and fit the story well. Its not particulry amazing, but it does its job, and well.Art: Cartoony, friendly, and well done. This Game's Design is defintly one of its strong suits.The end result: A far too short game with flaws, but in its defense, it the 1st part of a new project by indie developers. One does not have to work hard to give them some slack, and with said slack this was a fun and thougly enjoyable half hour. Yes, it was short, but I think this was a more of a testing of the waters to see if anyone was truly interested in this game, and it deserves some attention. And for pete's sake , its free! And when if they iron out the flaws I mentioned, it will definitly be worth spending money on (provided they don't ask too high a price, and that's a mistake anyone can make).

												Reversion: Chapter 1, is the first of many chapters in the game series Reversion, by 3f Interactive. In this game you will be taking on the role of a character who has no memory of his past. All he knows is that mysteriously 20 years seem to have disappeared, and he has no idea what his name is. You will find yourself in a hospital that has seen better days, and it appears that there is a group of mercenaries determined to keep you right where you are.Graphically I think this game looks solid. Now I fully understand that this is not a game that was first created for English speaking individuals, and perhaps they didn't have anyone who really knew English grammar all that well, but for an English speaker, it was a bit difficult.The controls were your average mouse adventure game. There's also a button that kind of looks like a radar screen that when clicked upon will highlight all the objects that you can in some shape or form interact with.Alright so lets get into this game, you are a person who knows some stuff, but doesn't know the important stuff, such as name, or the actual year. 												At the moment of writing this review it's ​09.15.2014. And now, at this moment, I'm gonna give the game a thumbs up...Let's first talk about bad stuff, then the good, then I'll try and explain the overall impression and why I've given it positive grade. The game has many things against it - the voice over is bad. The char's are flat and lifeless, and translation is abysmal with lots of non-sequiturs and seemingly butchered meanings, but which uninterrupted went on to voice actors, to sound mixers, to testers. Easily it could have been done far more satisfactory. The graphics are simple and remind me of late 2000s flash animation style. There is no option for full HD resolution. Even in my full HD full screen, there are black borders, the game doesn't scale up. There's not much music, nor sound effects. UI is clunky with option wheel which has to be pressed for a second to open, and no way to change default function (there's only three - look, talk, use/take) and always use the same click for it. But what's good with the game? The setting is unique in more than one way - not just that it's set in Argentina, Buenos Aires, but in the future of the city where some cataclysm devastated the city and supposedly made an independent militia controlled city-state of it. Even in this golden age of indie development, it's extremely rare to experience something which isn't centered in standard circle of western culture in adventure games. It's either some traditional western(ised) setting (say US, New Orleans for Gabriel Knight, Paris for Broken Sword), or some extremely exotic setting like dungeons, far future, or jungle temples. Usually it's completely ignored that there are millions, if not billions of people living in some different urban settings which aren't either New York, or, say, far east. This game allows me to experience different culture. So that's a great plus in my books. The standard adventure gameplay mechanic flows nicely. There is a hint function, so I was never stuck for long. Usage of objects is logical, there's no "use brick on tin can to squish it open and then use antique wig to gather the tomato sauce"* nonsense, even though actual intentions and objectives could have been expressed better. As said, hints keep the game going nicely. And it's short and sweet having no delusions of grandeur. It's an indie game through and through. More importantly, even with that about shortness said, the sense of mystery and adventure hits the precise spot I had from the days of the Curse of the Monkey IslandTM. I want to explore further, I want to learn the story and the world. I want some answers goshdarnit! Big plus there!But what's the most positive sign, and the reason I've started this review with a date of all things - is the price. The first episode is free on Steam. Second episode is out and I got it in a humble sale. I started playing it, but quickly the same sense of mystery forced me to download this one and find out how the story started. There are lots of negative reviews, here on Steam, but now, at this date, with these conditions, there's no reason why you shouldn't try the first episode. It's an adventure snack. I actually waited for some other game to download and ended playing it till the end in 66 minutes.I remember the time not so long ago people said adventure games are dead. This isn't the game that will singlehandedly save the genre - it's the proof it's actually so much alive that the games are vital enough to develop in non-standard settings and tell non-standard stories from small developing teams who don't even bother to translate their official game blog to english. It is what it is. And, considering the price, yes. You should try it.*NOT an actual example!

The pacing of the lines is horrible as well, there's no pause in between them so everything has this weird rushed feel, despite the lines themselves being slowly paced.The dialogue itself is pretty horrendous as well. After establishing SWM's amnesia we go on to learn that a civil war has broken out and that it is 20 years later than SWM thought it was. Apparently he's a time traveller too or something stupid like that. There's also a doctor, a love interest (sorry, "woman") called "Victoria" and a soldier, though everyone seems to be avoiding the word "soldier". Since I got bored of the game very early on, I'm just going to guess the rest of the plot. SWM and Victoria escape the hospital and join up with "The Resistance". Through a series of misadventures they work hard to bring down whatever the other faction is, as Victoria's heart warms to SWM (possibly due to his charismatic blandness), Eventually they kill Hitler or whatever and fall in love.The voice acting. Oh god, the voice acting. Everything is flat and emotionless, the doctor being the worst offender. The pacing of the lines is horrible as well, there's no pause in between them so everything has this weird rushed feel, despite the lines themselves being slowly paced.The dialogue itself is pretty horrendous as well. It's fairly obvious that it wasn't written natively in English : not in itself a bad thing but the translation has been done poorly. There are odd quirks in the subject matter as well, where it is painfully obvious that the characters are speaking around the plot in order to hide information from the player, so that they can find it out later on and be surprised.As far as gameplay goes: it's a traditional point/click escape game. The puzzles don't make any sense so you have to just wander around all the areas at a painfully slow pace, clicking everything and combining everything with everything else.
